  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/deals/186252-et-deals-dell-ultrasharp-uz2715h-27-inch-ips-monitor-for-360" rel="next" title="ET deals: Dell UltraSharp UZ2715H 27-inch IPS monitor for $360"/>

          #stickybanner,

      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/electronics" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Electronics category archives.">
           Electronics
          </a>

        <li class="current_item">
         Harvesting energy from humidity: Free, green energy from leaping water droplets
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           Harvesting energy from humidity: Free, green energy from leaping water droplets
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/rwhitwam" rel="author" title="Posts by Ryan Whitwam">
              Ryan Whitwam
             </a>
             on July 14, 2014 at 3:01 pm
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="186215 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=186215" href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/186215-harvesting-energy-from-humidity-free-green-energy-from-leaping-water-droplets#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Hydrophobic" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="353" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Hydrophobic-640x353.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Its time to get rid of that dehumidifier  you are just throwing away
            <em>
             free
            </em>
            energy by sucking all the moisture out of the air, according to some new research published by a team from
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/tag/mit">
             MIT
            </a>
            . Postdoc researchers Nenad Miljkovic and engineering professor Evelyn Wang figured out last year that water droplets jumping off a hydrophobic surface could gain an electric charge, but now theyre worked out how to capture that energy, essentially pulling power out of thin air.
           </p>
           <p>
            The team happened upon this mechanism quite by accident. The goal when the leaping water was discovered was to design a more efficient heat transfer material for power plants. Thats not nearly as sexy as conjuring power from humidity, but Miljkovic and Wang noticed something odd when working with a super-hydrophobic surface (pictured above). The condensing water droplets sometimes spontaneously jumped away from the hydrophobic surface, which was the goal as it cools much more efficiently. They didnt expect the water droplets to produce an electric charge in the process, and that may have significant ramifications.
           </p>
           <p>
            Its the natural tendency of water to flow away from a hydrophobic surface, but in turning the leaping water into a viable method of power generation, the researchers had to give it somewhere to go. To encourage the water droplets to take a leap, a
            <em>
             hydrophilic
            </em>
            surface was placed just above the hydrophobic one. So the
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/tag/water">
             water
            </a>
            <em>
             really
            </em>
            wants to make the trip from hydrophobic to hydrophilic, and it brings a few electrons along for the ride. The charge difference between the two plates can then be used to provide power.
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/2014-07-14-05_45_02-scitation.aip_.org_docserver_fulltext_aip_journal_apl_105_1_1.4886798.pdf_expires.png">
             <img alt="Water Droplets" class="size-large wp-image-186216" height="242" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/2014-07-14-05_45_02-scitation.aip_.org_docserver_fulltext_aip_journal_apl_105_1_1.4886798.pdf_expires-640x242.png" width="640"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            The stunning thing here is how simple the generator is  its composed of two interleaved metal plates with coatings that either attract or repel water, withno moving parts. The prototype used copper because its highly conductive (the same reason its used in telecommunications), but a cheaper metal like aluminum could work too. The main property that makes the leaping water generator good for producing power is surface area  just like a radiators fins dissipate heat. The more fins you can pack in, the more water droplets are going to be going on a trip to the hydrophilic side.
           </p>
           <p>
            Youre probably wondering how much power this process produces. Well, lets just say you wont be breaking free of
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/155036-florida-rolls-out-large-scale-smart-grid-puts-rest-of-country-to-shame">
             the power grid
            </a>
            just yet. In their experiments, Miljkovic and Wang were able to harvest about 15 picowatts per square centimeter of metal, but they believe
            <a href="http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2014-07/miot-gac071114.php">
             at least 1 microwatt is possible
            </a>
            with some tweaking. At that efficiency level, a cube-shaped generator 50 centimeters on a side (like a small camping cooler) could charge a cell phone in 12 hours. It also needs to be in a humid environment to capture the condensing water from the air. So your damp basement, sure. The living room? Probably not. Many tropical regions are also sufficiently humid for the system to work. [Read:
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/160634-ambient-backscatter-free-energy-harvesting-from-tv-signals-to-power-a-ubiquitous-internet-of-things">
             Ambient backscatter: Free energy harvesting from TV signals, to power a ubiquitous internet of things
            </a>
            .]
           </p>
           <p>
            This isnt going to power nations or anything, but the water condensing generator is about as close to free energy as you can get right now. There are no moving parts to replace, no hazardous waste from manufacturing, and it works passively all the time so no one needs to know how to operate it. A larger unit could juice up cell phones in remote areas, or even give your electric car a few extra milliampere-hours
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/184141-tesla-reveals-plan-to-share-supercharger-network-with-other-electric-car-makers">
             when theres not a plug available
            </a>
            .
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-text-links',
        placement: 'Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">

          <div class="widget column widget_disquswidget" id="disquswidget-3">

           </script>

            </h3>

               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-309990">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-309990">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-309990">
                  Simon
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-309990">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-309990">
                 <p>
                  Miljkovic and Wang were able to harvest about 15 picowatts per square centimeter of metal, but they believe at least 1 microwatt is possible with some tweaking
                  <br/>
                  1 microwatt is negligibly small. Its useless. What voltage did they measure?
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-310034">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-310034">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-310034">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-310034">
                  johnbales
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-310034">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-310034">
                 <p>
                  Its been so humid here in southwest AR for the last two weeks that its almost hard to breathe. Makes me wonder how much energy potential there is in several square miles after reading this.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-310076">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-310076">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-310076">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-310076">
                  BillBasham
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-310076">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-310076">
                 <p>
                  Honestly, the opening statement of this article seems more significant than the energy harvesting.  If I could dehumidify my house without using significant energy, it would have a major impact on my energy usage.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-310097">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-310097">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-310097">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-310097">
                  Ray C
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-310097">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-310097">
                 <p>
                  I guess over time well see where this research goes
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-310134">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-310134">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-310134">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-310134">
                  Lance
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-310134">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-310134">
                 <p>
                  In large scale, wonder what kind environmental displacement we could see from this. The idea of free energy has always been a pipe dream of science,
                  <br/>
                  Hydroelectric power effects its ecosystem.
                  <br/>
                  Wind farms effect their ecosystem.
                  <br/>
                  Nuclear power at first glance is fairly clean, but the waste severely effects its environment.
                  <br/>
                  Coal and other fossil fuels, natural gas, etc etc.. all effect their environments.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Now maybe, Im misreading this, but it appears to be claiming free energy through the reclamation of the energy released when the water is ejected from the surface. I suppose this could somehow be included in a hydroelectric dam to increase overall efficiency or capacity, but simply from removing humidity from the air what % local humidity are we talking? I just see too many questions. Hopefully in the next few years we see this come to maturity.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-310400">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-310400">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-310400">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-310400">
                    ehsansia
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-310400">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-310400">
                   <p>
                    Well In larger scales and for industrial or commercial purposes they could implement several layers to form a thick pack of radiators stacked upon each other. In this way they may save space and produce higher power.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-313472">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-313472">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-313472">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-313472">
                  Mr Moo
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-313472">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-313472">
                 <p>
                  Other than sucking a bit more power out of the cooling systems in power stations, this is pretty pointless, charging your phone isnt exactly going to surge the power grid and a few extra milliamp hours in an EV is nothing, youd probably use more energy moving the extra weight.
                  <br/>
                  Its just an interesting discovery that might give someone a better idea one day
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-320574">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-320574">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-320574">
                 http://www.enviroequipment.com
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-320574">
                  Enviro Equipment, Inc.
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-320574">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-320574">
                 <p>
                  Im sure that any potential technology that uses humidity as a power source would be more suited for tropical areas or at least near the ocean and probably only on a small scale basis such as for a small home.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
             </ul>
            </div>
           </div>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var disqus_url = 'http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/186215-harvesting-energy-from-humidity-free-green-energy-from-leaping-water-droplets';
    var disqus_identifier = '186215 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=186215';
    var disqus_container_id = 'disqus_thread';
    var disqus_domain = 'disqus.com';
    var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
    var disqus_title = "Harvesting energy from humidity: Free, green energy from leaping water droplets";
        var disqus_config = function () {
        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=186215';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var DsqLocal = {

           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */

    var dsq = document.createElement('script'); dsq.type = 'text/javascript';
    dsq.async = true;
    dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.' + 'disqus.com' + '/embed.js?pname=wordpress&amp;pver=2.74';
    (document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]).appendChild(dsq);

           </script>

      <div class="content">
       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Electronics'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Ryan Whitwam';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});
        </script>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
